document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic note on the oil-collecting bee Centris dimidiata (Olivier, 1789) (Hymenoptera: Apidae: Centridini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic note on the oil-collecting bee Centris dimidiata (Olivier, 1789) (Hymenoptera: Apidae: Centridini)

heading.emphasis:
Centris ( Melacentris ) furcata ( Fabricius, 1804 )
nom. rev.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Female: Fore elaiospathe with anterior secondary comb formed by five giant, apically curved hairs. Primary pygidial plate relatively rhomboid, with posterior margin of secondary plate not projected backwards ( Fig. 10 ). Male: Clypeus finely areolate with relatively fine and dense punctures laterally, with longitudinal impunctate area on disc. Mediotarsus of hind leg without tuft of plumose hairs ventrally; distitarsus with yellow, dense, plumose hairs forming a comb. Base of hind claw with tuft of branched pubescence, with some simple hairs intermixed ( Fig. 16 ). Mandible strongly curved apically with three teeth (2nd>1st≈3rd): apical tooth with acute apex, second straight and third rounded ( Figs. 4 , 14 ). This species is most similar to
C . atriventris
. Females differ by the width of the mandibular teeth (1st>2nd>4th>3rd in
C . furcata
, Fig. 3 ; 1st>3rd>4th>2nd in
C . atriventris
, Fig. 1 ), by the coloration of the clypeus (dark brown in
C . furcata
, Fig. 3 ; orange brown in
C . atriventris
, Fig. 1 ) and by the shape of the secondary basitibial plate (not projected backwards in
C . furcata
, Fig. 10 ; projected backwards in
C . atriventris
, Fig. 9 ). Males differ mainly by the size of the second and third mandibular teeth (2nd>3rd in
C . furcata
, Fig. 14 ; 3rd>2nd in
C . atriventris
, Fig. 13 ) and by the absence of a tuft of branched hairs at the base of the hind pretarsal claws ( Fig. 16 ), which is present in
C . atriventris
( Fig. 15 ).

Female ( Figs. 3 , 7 , 10, 12 ). Measurements: Approximate body length: 33.0; head width: 8.3; thorax width: 10.5; forewing length: 19.0; UID: 3.8; LID: 3.9; mandible length: 3.6; mandible basal width: 1.7; F1 length: 2.1; F2 length: 0.4; F3 length: 0.5. Coloration: Integument dark brown except as follows: clypeus, labrum, mandible, and basitibial and pygidial plates reddish brown ( Figs. 3 , 10 ). Legs light brown ( Fig. 7 ). Lower paraocular area, scape, pronotum, propodeum, and tegula yellowish brown ( Figs. 3 , 7 ). Wing membrane and veins dark brown ( Fig. 7 ) with green/violaceous iridescence. Sculpture: Clypeus finely areolate, more evident towards upper half, with relatively thin and dense punctures towards laterosuperior margin (di<ds). Clypeal disc with fine and sparse punctures (di<ds). Surface near lower edge of clypeus with some coarse and fine punctures intermixed. Labrum with relatively fine, very dense and uniform punctures (di≈ds). T1 with fine and not very dense punctures. T2 and T3 with very fine, dense and uniform punctures, almost reaching distal edge (di≈ds). T4 and T5 with similar punctures to basal terga, but with some coarse punctures intermixed. Pubescence: Frons, vertex and metasoma with dark brown almost black pilosity, the rest of head with brown hairs ( Figs. 3 , 7 ). Mesepisternum with light orange hairs with dark orange tips ( Fig. 7 ); light brown and simple hairs ventrally. Propodeum with light brown plumose pubescence. Mesoscutum and mesoscutellum with intense orange hairs with dark orange tips ( Figs. 3 , 7 ). Legs with light brown pilosity, mainly on fore legs ( Fig. 7 ). Labrum with brown branched pubescence, interspersed with simple, downwardly directed hairs ( Fig. 3 ). Terga, except T1, with dense pubescence. T1 with branched hairs mainly at sides. Prepygidial fimbriae with brown plumose pilosity covered by coarse and simple hairs ( Fig. 12 ). Pygidial fimbria with coarse and simple hairs ( Fig. 12 ). Structures: Flabellum elliptical with slightly narrow anterior margin. Mandible strongly curved apically with four teeth (1st>2nd≈4th>3rd) of acute apex, except fourth truncated ( Fig. 3 ). Acetabular carina reaching base of fourth tooth ( Fig. 3 ). Trimal angle well-developed, acute. Maxillary palpus with four palpomeres (2nd>3rd>1st>4th). Clypeus convex with lower half concave (lateral view). Labrum relatively triangular ( Fig. 3 ). Vertex above upper interocular tangent ( Fig. 3 ). Inner orbits of compound eyes relatively parallel ( Fig. 3 ). Mesoscutellum with two not well-developed protuberances. Axilla raised and covered by hairs. Primary pygidial plate with slightly concave apex (straight in some specimens) ( Fig. 12 ); secondary plate well-developed with acute apex ( Fig. 12 ). Pretarsal claws with preapical tooth, except on hind leg. Male ( Figs. 4 , 8 , 14, 16 ). Description: Measurements: Approximate body length: 28.0; head width: 8.0; thorax width: 10.3; forewing length: 21.0; UID: 2.5; LID: 3.4; mandible length: 3.5; mandible basal width: 1.7; F1 length: 1.8; F2 length: 0.4; F3 length: 0.5. Coloration: Frons, vertex and metasoma dark brown ( Figs. 4 , 8 ). Supraclypeal and lower paraocular areas, clypeus and labrum yellow ( Fig. 4 ). Mandible, legs and pygidial plates brown ( Figs. 4 , 14 ). Tegula yellowish brown ( Fig. 8 ). Wing membrane and veins dark brown ( Fig. 8 ) with green/violaceous iridescence. Sculpture: Labrum with relatively fine, dense and uniform punctures with well-defined smooth upper area (di≈ds). T1 finely areolate with fine and not very dense punctures. T2 and T3 with very fine, dense and uniform punctures almost reaching distal edge (di≈ds). T4 and T5 with similar punctures to basal terga with some coarser punctures intermixed. T6 with coarse, scattered punctures. Pubescence: Head, pronotum (except lobe), metasoma, tibiae and tarsi of middle and hind legs with dark brown almost black hairs ( Figs. 4 , 8 ). Middle trochanter, hind coxa and mesepisternum with yellow pubescence ( Fig. 8 ). Mesoscutum, mesoscutellum, area below wings and tegula with light orange hairs with slightly darker tips ( Fig. 8 ). Fore leg (except femur) with brown pilosity ( Fig. 8 ). Femora with yellowish brown hairs ( Fig. 8 ). Propodeum with light brown and yellowish brown pubescence. T1 with dark brown plumose hairs. T2 and T3 with dense, branched pilosity. T4–T6 with plumose dense hairs. Structures: Flabellum elliptical with slightly narrow anterior margin. Acetabular carina reaching base of second tooth ( Fig. 14 ). Trimal angle well-developed, acute ( Fig. 14 ). Maxillary palpus with four palpomeres (2nd≈3rd>4th>1st). Clypeal disc slightly convex (lateral view). Labrum slightly triangular with rounded distal margin ( Fig. 14 ). Vertex above upper interocular tangent ( Fig. 4 ). Inner orbits of compound eyes converging upwards ( Fig. 4 ). Mesoscutellum with two well-developed protuberances. Axilla raised and glabrous. Pygidial plate with bilobed apex. Variation: Female with pubescence on mesoscutum and mesoscutellum slightly yellowish to dark orange. Male’s metasoma with brownish integument.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 17–20. Fig. 17.
Centris
dimidiata
(Olivier, 1789)
. Neotype female (Brazil: Porto Velho): Head, frontal view (scale bar 1 mm). Fig. 18. Neotype female: Habitus, lateral view (scale bar 5 mm). Fig. 19. Male (Brazil: Porto Velho): Head, frontal view (scale bar 1 mm). Fig. 20. Male: Habitus, lateral view (scale bar 5 mm).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality.
“America meridionali” [‘Ex. Am. mer Schmidt.’] probably British Guiana (see Moure 1960a and Papavero 1971 ) ( Fig. 22 ).

Distribution ( Fig. 25 ). * BRAZIL :
AMAZONAS :
Beneficente (Rio Aripuanã), Manaus, Novo Airão, Palmari, Santa Isabel do Rio Negro (Tapuruquara), Seis Lagos, Tabatinga, Uaupes. PA R Á: Óbidos, Santarém, Serra dos Carajás.
RONDÔNIA :
Pimenta Bueno. * SURINAME :
SIPALIWINI :
Table Mountain.
